newsitem.title: USA: IPO HIGHLIGHTS-Galileo jumps at debut.
newsitem.headline: IPO HIGHLIGHTS-Galileo jumps at debut.

text.p: Galileo Technology Ltd shares surged more than 58 percent on its first day of trading Tuesday from its initial public offering price of $17 a share.
The stock was up 9-7/8 to 26-7/8 in late trading on the Nasdaq. Galileo, which makes semiconductors for digital communication network equipment, sold three million shares.

In the original U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the Karmiel, Israel-based company expected to sell 250,000 fewer shares for between $10 to $12 each. The underwriters, led by Alex Brown & Sons, have an option to buy 450,000 more shares to cover any over-allotments, if any.
Other companies that made their IPO debuts today:

-- Bioreliance Corp shares jumped to 18 from an IPO price of $15 a share, above initial expectations. It first set a pricing range for the 2.4 million shares offered at $12-$14 but raised the range to $14 to $15 due to heavy demand. It sold 2.1 million of the total shares while selling shareholders offered the remainder. Morgan Stanley Dean Witter was the lead underwriter of the offering.
Bioreliance, based in Rockville, Maryland, provides nonclinical testing and contract manufacturing services to biotechnology companies. It was founded as Microbiological Associates Inc in 1947.

The company said it would used for capital expenditures, expansion of viral manufacturing capabilities, working capital and other general corporate purposes, including potential acquisitions, the company said.
-- Shares of Net.B@nk Inc slid on their first day of trading despite a generally favorable climate for IPOs.

The Atlanta internet bank sold 3.5 million shares, up from an original plan to offer three million, for $12 each, the top of its estimated price range of $10 to $12. Morgan Keegan & Co Inc was the lead underwriter of the offering.
